bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R. S. Galbreath, July 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench inquires into the health of Kissinger who suffered a debilitating stroke.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R. S. Galbreath, July 2, 1941
div1.opener:
COPY
July 2, 1941
Dr. R. S. Galbreath
16 W. Washington St.
Huntington, Indiana
My dear Doctor Galbreath:
div1.p:
I hope you will not mind my intruding with the affairs of Mr.
and Mrs. Kissinger. I have known them for some years and have admired Mr. Kissinger
for his service to humanity and his simple, lovable character. I was at the meet-
ing in Cleveland with him two days before he had his stroke. I sincerely hope you
will not think me presumptuous for discussing his case with you.

First of all, I shall appreciate knowing just what his condition
is. Mrs. Kissinger told me that he had a very severe stroke, was paralyzed on his
right side and that he had notable speech and even some visual impairment. In her
letters to me, she complains rather bitterly about her own difficulties and seems
to be much distressed that her backache and other symptoms prevent her from taking
proper care of Mr. Kissinger. Regardless of how much she is ailing, I am thinking
primarily of Mr. Kissinger and wondering whether you would think his condition such
that he will probably never recover the use of his limbs or perhaps not for months.
If this eventuality faces him, do you think he would rather be confined to his
home, surrounded by friends, or do you think he might be better off, at least for
a while in some army or veterans' hospital. Mrs. Kissinger infers that they do not
have enough money for her to get any help and that it is most difficult for her
to take care of him. I have not breathed a word to Mrs. Kissinger about my
suggestion as to hospitalization elsewhere, as I of course wanted to discuss the
matter with you, but if you think he is badly and permanently incapacitated and in
need of hospital care, perhaps we could set in motion arrangements to get him in
a nearby veterans' hospital or even in Walter Reed Hospital in Washington. Most
of the army men in the medical department know of Mr. Kissinger and I think they
might out red tape and do what they could for him. Perhaps I am wrong, but at least
I wanted to get your reaction to this. As to the matter of transportation, that
would of course depend on his condition and whether or when you thought he might be
moved, either by train, ambulance or plane.

As I said before, I don't want to intrude in the professional re-
lationship you have with him but I don't imagine he is any financial help to you
and I have no doubt that you would be glad to share the burden of his care.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
